Low temperature SCR has been a promising technology due to the diverse load in coal-fired plants. However, ammonia escape problem could be more serious at low temperature on account of the condensation of NH4HSO4, resulting in deactivation of SCR catalyst and equipment corrosion. NH3-SCO technology could oxidize slip ammonia to harmless N2. Hence, it is important to develop a novel catalyst with high SCR and SCO efficiency at low temperature to remove NOx and slip NH3 and achieve the stable operation of SCR system. In this work, a combined sol-gel and impregnation method was used to synthetize different Aga−Mn/Ce-Ti (a = 2%, 5%, 8%) catalysts and applied in NOx and slip NH3 removal at low temperature. The activity measurement confirmed that Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst exhibited an excellent low-temperature performance. At 150–300 °C, its NO conversion was 100%, NH3 conversion was above 95% and N2 selectivity was more than 90%. Moreover, considering the oxidation of slip ammonia, Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst also exhibited above 90% NH3 conversion at 200–350 °C in the absence of NO. The catalytic performance could also be kept at a high level under the existence of SO2 and H2O. The characteristic results revealed that Ag and Mn modification could not apparently change the phase structure and could decrease the BET area to some extent. In addition, Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst possessed stronger and more surface acidic sites and contributed to better NH3 adsorption capacity. Besides, there was more chemisorbed oxygen on Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst resulting from the interactions among Ag, Mn and Ce oxides, which was responsible for its better redox property. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ag modification Ce-Ti catalyst Low-temperature SCR Slip ammonia Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides are one of the main atmospheric pollutants existing currently in the world, which are created from mobile sources like diesel exhaust gas and stationary sources like coal-fired plants. NOx can do serious harm to the environment by bringing about acid rain, greenhouse effect and photochemical smog [1–4]. As coal-fired power plants are still the main sources for electricity production, NOx emission is unavoidable at present. NH3-SCR (selective catalytic reduction by NH3) is the most widely applied technology to eliminate NOx from the industrial system. Efficient SCR catalyst is the core of the technology. V2O5-WO3-TiO2 and V2O5−MoO3-TiO2 are two practical catalysts with high NOx removal efficiency [5–7]. Nevertheless, there are still lots of serious problems in SCR part, like the toxicity of V-based catalysts and the narrow reaction temperature window from 300 to 400 °C. In fact, in view of firing various kind of coal and changing load frequently in utility boiler, the actual temperature of the flue gas in coal-fired plants could be lower than 300 °C [8–10]. Moreover, the exhaust gas temperature in many other industries could be lower, like steel and glass industry. Hence, it is important to develop novel non‑vanadium materials with good low temperature SCR activity. Currently, Mn oxide caught attention in low temperature SCR reaction due to its excellent catalytic performance. Based on the active component Mn, many catalysts like Mn-Co/Ti, Mn-Fe/Ti and MnWO3 could all show good NOx removal performance at low temperature [11–15]. Apart from this, Ce-based catalysts has attracted much interest on account of its sufficient oxygen vacancy generated by the cycle between Ce4+ and Ce3+. It has been investigated that the loading of Mn could improve the interaction between manganese and cerium oxides and enhance the percentage of Mn4+, which was conducive to improve SCR performance [16–19]. On the other hand, as ammonia is injected in the flue gas to eliminate NOx, NH3 escape problem becomes unavoidable in SCR system. Due to the complexity of SCR operation conditions and the deactivation of SCR catalyst, NH3 could not be totally consumed in SCR reactor [20–22]. The excessive ammonia discharged into the atmosphere can join in the formation of atmospheric aerosols and result in soil acidification, which can adversely influence the environment and human health [23,24]. Furthermore, slip ammonia in the flue gas can also react with sulfur oxides to form ammonium hydrogen sulfate. When the reaction temperature is lower than 300 °C, NH4HSO4 can gradually condense and become vicious. It can result in the deactivation of SCR catalyst and the corrosion and scaling of denitrification equipment, which seriously endangers the long-term stable operation of the system [25–28]. Therefore, the ammonia escape problem at low temperature is more harmful and should be paid more attention. However, few studies have focused on slip ammonia problem in low temperature SCR reaction, which may bring risks to the practical application and operation of the catalysts. Among all the methods to remove ammonia, NH3-SCO (selective catalytic oxidation of NH3) has attracted much attention on account of its high efficiency, stability and economy [29–31]. Moreover, in NH3-SCO reaction, NH3 was oxidized by O2 to form N2 and H2O, which is environmentally friendly and avoid the secondary pollution [32–34]. The most crucial part in NH3-SCO technology is to develop an effective catalyst. Based on previous literature, the active component in NH3-SCO could be divided into two categories: noble metals and transition metals. Transition metals owned the advantages of low price and high efficiency. Cu/Al2O3, Cu/TiO2, Fe-Mg-Al, Fe-ZSM-5 could all show excellent NH3 removal rate over 85% and their N2 selectivity was more than 90% [35–39]. However, their active temperature was generally higher than 300 °C. By comparison, noble metal catalysts could show high NH3 oxidation performance at low temperature. Pt-Fe-Ti, Ag/Al2O3, Pd-ZSM-5 could achieve more than 90% NH3 oxidation efficiency below 250 °C and Ag-based catalyst showed better N2 selectivity [40–44]. Furthermore, it has been well established that Ag-based SCR catalysts owned good low temperature denitrification performance. For example, Ag-Mn-Ce/γ-Al2O3 could show 95% NOx conversion at 250 °C [45]. Therefore, Ag modification has been considered to enhance catalytic activity at low temperature to effectively eliminate slip ammonia. Overall, it is of great value to develop a novel catalyst to remove NOx as well as control slip ammonia at low temperature. In this research, Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalysts with different Ag loading amount were synthetized by impregnation and sol-gel methods. The NH3-SCO and NH3-SCR activity of these samples were investigated to select the most suitable catalyst. The influences of SO2 and H2O were also measured to simulate the actual flue gas condition. The characterization experiments BET, XRD and TEM were used to measure the physical characteristics. Additionally, XPS, H2-TPR and NH3-TPD were carried out to examine the chemical properties, including the valence, redox qualities and surface acidity. This research proposed a potential high-efficient catalyst to realize the collaborative control of denitrification and ammonia escape at low temperature, which owned a promising prospect in the industrial application. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Sol-gel method was used to prepare Ce-Ti catalyst (the ratio of Ce/Ti = 0.25). To be specific, 6.2 g Ce(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in anhydrous ethanol and deionized water and form Solution A. Then the Solution A was added to Solution B which was consist of anhydrous ethanol and 56 ml butyl titanate. The process was under vigorous stirring and the mixture was kept at room temperature for 24 h. Subsequently, the mixture was dried at 85 °C for 16 h and calcined at 500 °C in air for 4 h. Impregnated method was used to synthesize Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst. The desired amount of AgNO3 and Mn(NO3)2 was dissolved in deionized water and then the prepared Ce-Ti catalyst was added in the solution. The obtained solution was then dried at 105 °C for 16 h and calcined at 500 °C in air for 4 h. The mass ratio of manganese was 10% and that of silver was 2%, 5%, 8%. The catalysts were denoted as Ce-Ti, Mn/Ce-Ti, Ag2-Mn/Ce-Ti, Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti, Ag8-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization A BET area analyzer APAP 2020 was used to test the BET area by N2 adsorption-desorption. The desorption temperature was 300 °C and desorption time was 6 h. XRD was tested from 10° to 90° by an instrument D/MX-IIA. The TEM and HRTEM were carried out by an electron microscope (JEM-2100). ESCALAB 250Xi was used to measure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and the patterns for Ag3d, Ce3d, O1s, Mn2p were investigated with Al Kα radiation. The NH3-TPD experiment was conducted to get a better understanding of the surface acidity of the catalysts by AutoChem II 2920 analyzer. 200 mg sample was pretreated in the helium atmosphere at 400 °C for 1 h and then cooled to the room temperature. Subsequently, the catalysts were treated with ammonia for an hour and then heated to 600 °C in helium in 60 min. The H2-TPR curves were also examined by AutoChem II 2920 analyzer. Similarly, the samples were pretreated in helium and then heated in 50 mL/min 1%H2-Ar to 800 °C by 10 °C/min. 2.3 Activity test 0.5 g Ce-Ti, Mn/Ce-Ti and Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalysts were prepared to carry out the NH3-SCR and NH3-SCO performance test in a fixed bed quartz reactor. The total flue gas flow was 1 L/min and the simulated flue gas included 500 ppm NO, 500 or 50 ppm NH3, 500 ppm SO2 (when used), 6% H2O (when used), 5%O2 and N2. The GHSV was 4 × 104 h−1 and the reaction time was 1 h. The NO reduction efficiency, NH3 oxidation efficiency and N2 selectivity were calculated through the following 4 equations: (1) NO removal efficiency = [ 1 − [ N O ] o u t + [ N O 2 ] o u t [ N O ] i n ] × 100 % (2) N H 3 removal efficiency = [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N H 3 ] o u t [ N H 3 ] i n × 100 % (3) N 2 selectivit y a = [ 1 − [ N O 2 ] o u t + 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t [ N O ] i n + [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N H 3 ] o u t − [ N O ] o u t ] × 100 % (4) N 2 selectivit y b = [ 1 − [ N O ] o u t + [ N O 2 ] o u t + 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N H 3 ] o u t ] × 100 % N2 selectivitya and N2 selectivityb were used in NH3-SCR and NH3-SCO performance tests, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3-SCR performance The NO conversion, NH3 conversion and N2 selectivity of four catalysts were displayed in Fig. 1 . It was visible that the NO and NH3 conversion improved as the temperature increased. At 100 °C, the NO conversion of all catalysts was less than 30%. NO reduction efficiency of Ce-Ti catalyst rose from 9 to 92% as the temperature rose from 100 to 300 °C and then decreased to 83% at 350 °C. Mn modification significantly enhanced the SCR activity of Ce-Ti catalyst, especially in low temperature. Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst exhibited above 95% NO conversion from 200 to 300 °C. The loading of Ag further improved the low-temperature SCR activity of Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst. At 150 °C, the NO removal efficiency of Ag2-Mn/Ce-Ti, Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti, Ag8-Mn/Ce-Ti catalysts reached 84, 100 and 100%. Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti and Ag8-Mn/Ce-Ti catalysts showed 100% NO conversion at a wide temperature range from 150 to 300 °C. On the other hand, the NH3 conversion showed a similar trend among CeTi, Mn/Ce-Ti and Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalysts. At 150 °C, the NH3 oxidation efficiency of Ce-Ti, Mn/Ce-Ti, Ag2-Mn/Ce-Ti, Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti, Ag8-Mn/Ce-Ti catalysts was 20%, 44%, 81%, 95% and 98%, respectively. When the temperature was higher than 200 °C, the NH3 oxidation efficiency of the samples modified with Ag reached 100%. What's more, it could be found that the NH3 removal efficiency was lower than that of NO, which suggested that the ratio of NH3/NO in SCR process was not strictly 1:1 [34]. The phenomenon also provided the possibility of ammonia escape problem in SCR reaction. Furthermore, in SCR process, except for harmless final product N2 and H2O, there was also other by-products like N2O and NO2, which could lead to the secondary pollution. The reactions were as follows [46,47]: (5) 4 N H 3 + 7 O 2 → 4 N O 2 + 6 H 2 O (6) 2 N H 3 + 2 O 2 → N 2 O + 3 H 2 O (7) 4 N H 3 + 5 O 2 → 4 NO + 6 H 2 O (8) 4 N H 3 + 3 O 2 → 2 N 2 + 6 H 2 O So N2 selectivity was also an important index when we evaluated a SCR catalyst. With regard to N2 selectivity, it decreased dramatically with the increasing temperature. After loading Mn and Ag on Ce-Ti catalyst, N2 selectivity dropped in varying degrees. More Ag modification could result in lower N2 selectivity because of the stronger oxidation capacity [47]. Overall, considering NO conversion, N2 selectivity and the amount of Ag modification, Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti was the best sample, which exhibited 100% NO conversion at 150 °C. 3.2 NH3-SCO performance Due to the complex actual working condition of coal-fired plants, SCR efficiency is hard to reach 100%, which leads to excessive NH3 formation [34]. Therefore, as shown in Fig. 2 , NH3-SCO activity of different catalysts was observed to efficiently remove slip ammonia from SCR system. It could be found from Fig. 2(a) that the NH3 removal efficiency of Ce-Ti catalyst increased steadily from 100 to 300 °C and then increased rapidly from 39 to 72% when the temperature further grew to 350 °C. Compared with Ce-Ti catalyst, Mn modification could reduce the active temperature and improve SCO performance. The NH3 removal efficiency of Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst was 77% at 300 °C. What's more, the loading of Ag could significantly promote SCO activity. At 200 °C, the NH3 oxidation efficiency of Ag2-Mn/Ce-Ti, Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti, Ag8-Mn/Ce-Ti catalysts reached 74%, 92% and 94%, respectively. When the temperature was higher than 200 °C, Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti and Ag8-Mn/Ce-Ti could both achieve 100% NH3 conversion and showed a wide active temperature range. Furthermore, compared with the condition in the presence of NO, the NH3 oxidation ability reduced markedly, which indicated that NO was beneficial to NH3 oxidation as it could promote SCR reaction. As for N2 selectivity, excellent oxidation capacity could lead to excessively oxidation of ammonia and result in the formation of more by-product as well as the reduction in N2 selectivity. However, the N2 selectivity of these catalysts could keep at a relatively high level. At 200 °C, the N2 selectivity of Ce-Ti, Mn/Ce-Ti, Ag2-Mn/Ce-Ti, Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti, Ag8-Mn/Ce-Ti catalysts was 100%, 98%, 95%, 94% and 91%, respectively. Taking the amount of Ag loading, NH3 oxidation efficiency and N2 selectivity into consideration, Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst showed the most excellent SCO and SCR performance at low temperature. 3.3 Effect of GHSV The catalytic performance in different GHSV was also investigated to reveal the influence of GHSV and the results were displayed in Fig. S1. It could be observed that GHSV showed no obvious influence on the NH3 or NO removal efficiency at 200 °C, indicating that GHSV was not the important influence factor in SCO and SCR reaction. What's more, the GHSV of commercial SCR catalyst was usually 3000–5000 h−1 [29], which was markedly lower than the GHSV in the experiment, indicating that Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst could show good performance in the application. 3.4 Effect of SO2 and H2O In the actual working condition of coal-fired plants, SO2 and H2O were two of the main hazardous flue gas components, which could do harm to the activity of SCR catalyst. To simulate the actual flue gas, 500 ppm SO2 and 6% H2O were introduced in the atmosphere. Fig. 3 presented the effect of H2O and SO2 on the NO and NH3 conversion of Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst. It was obvious that SO2 and H2O could slightly reduce the catalytic performance. Without NO in the gas, NH3 oxidation efficiency at 200 °C decreased from 92 to 80% when H2O and SO2 were added in the simulated flue gas. The main reason was that SO2 could form sulfate with the metal oxides, reduce the amount of active component as well as compete with NH3 adsorption on the catalyst surface [48,49]. However, according to the previous literature, Ce was confirmed to preferentially react with SO2 to create sulfate, thus protected the active component and enhanced the SO2 resistance performance.H2O could also create a water film on the sample surface, which was detrimental to NH3 adsorption [50,51]. When the addition of SO2 and H2O was stopped, the NH3 conversion increased slightly but it was still lower than the original results. This phenomenon could be attributed to the residual sulfate on the sample surface, which hindered the oxidation of NH3 [50]. On the other hand, when NO was introduced in the atmosphere, the detrimental effects of SO2 and H2O became weaker. After adding H2O and SO2 in the flue gas for an hour, the NH3 and NO conversion efficiency dropped by 8% and 6%, respectively. The possible reason was that SO2 was demonstrated to create sulfate on the sample surface and then decreased the surface active sites and inhibited the oxidation of intermediate product NH2*to NOx(ad). However, when there was NO in the flue gas, it could directly form NOx(ad) on the catalyst surface and promote SCR process, thus reduced the adverse influence of SO2 [48]. Similarly, when SO2 and H2O were off, the NH3 and NO conversion enhanced slightly, but they were still lower than the initial results. Overall, Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst showed good resistance to SO2+H2O and maintained excellent SCO and SCR properties in the simulated flue gas condition. 3.5 BET BET surface area, pore volume and pore size of different samples were measured and the results were summarized in Table 1 . Among these raw and modified Ce-Ti catalysts, raw Ce-Ti catalyst presented the largest BET surface area of 122.6 m²/g and pore volume of 0.27 cm³/g. Mn modification significantly decrease the BET surface area and pore volume. What's more, the specific surface area of Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalysts also reduced markedly from 82.5 to 77.2 m²/g with the rise of the loading amount of Ag. A similar trend could be seen for the pore volume of Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalysts. These results could be owing to the phenomenon that the addition of Ag and Mn could block the pores on the catalyst [52], leading to the decrease of the specific surface area. However, considering the activity measurement results of these samples, it indicated that the catalytic properties were independent of these textural parameters. 3.6 XRD The XRD results of Ce-Ti, Mn/Ce-Ti and Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalysts were presented in Fig. 4 to show the phase structure of the samples. Obviously, all samples could only obtain several typical peaks corresponding to anatase TiO2. Mn or Ag modification made no difference to the intensity of TiO2 diffraction peaks regardless of the loading amount of Ag, which suggested that the crystallinity of TiO2 would not be significantly influenced by the loading of Mn or Ag. Moreover, no obvious diffraction peak of Mn or Ag oxides could be detected, indicating the well dispersion of manganese and silver species on Ce-Ti catalyst or their amorphous structure [53,54]. 3.7 TEM TEM and HRTEM images of three samples were displayed in Fig. 5 to show the microstructure influenced by Mn and Ag addition. It could be found from Fig. 5 that agglomerations formed on the catalyst surface. There was no apparent difference in their particle size or appearance when Mn and Ag was introduced in the catalyst. Based on HRTEM results, only anatase TiO2 of (101) lattice fringes (around 0.35 nm) could be observed. The phase of Ce, Mn or Ag species could not be detected, suggesting that these modified metals were highly dispersed on the surface [55]. The phenomenon was in agreement with the XRD results. 3.8 XPS XPS experiment was used to explore the surface atomic valence state of Ag, Mn, Ce and O. The XPS results of Ag3d, Mn2p, Ce3d, O1s were shown in Fig. 6 (a–d) and Table 2 , respectively. As displayed in Fig. 6a, the XPS pattern of Ag3d5/2 could be divided into two characteristic peaks. One of the peaks at low binding energy (367 eV) could be assigned to Ag+ and the other one at 366.3 eV could be assigned to Ag0 [56,57]. The peak area was calculated to show the percentage of Ag+ on the surface of Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst (Table 2). It was obvious that the ratio of Ag+ increased markedly with the Ag content among Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst. Ag8-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst presented the highest proportion of Ag+, accounting for 44.7% of the total content of Ag species. The Mn2p spectra of Mn/Ce-Ti and Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst was displayed in Fig. 6b. For all these catalysts, Mn2p3/2 consisted of two characteristic peaks centered at 639.6 eV and 640.9 eV, which correspond to Mn3+ and Mn4+, respectively [34]. The order of the proportion of Mn4+/(Mn4++Mn3+) was Ag8-Mn/Ce-Ti > Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti > Ag2-Mn/Ce-Ti > Mn/Ce-Ti, which demonstrated that Ag modification was conducive to enhance the formation of Mn4+ and the surface Mn4+ amount increased with the loading concentration of Ag. It was acknowledged that Mn4+ was conducive to enhance the oxidation ability of the catalysts [58], which contributed to the better catalytic performance. The Ce3d spectra of these raw and modified Ce-Ti catalysts was displayed in Fig. 6c. According to the available literature, Ce3d spectra mainly consisted of eight characteristic peaks: u, u1, u2, u3, v, v1, v2, v3. Among them, u1 and v1 could be attributed to Ce3+ and the other 6 peaks belonged to Ce4+ [47,51]. The percentage of surface Ce3+ amount was displayed in Table 2. It was evidently that the loading of Mn and Ag was advantageous to enhance the proportion of Ce3+ on the catalyst surface. More Ag content contributed to higher percentage of Ce3+. Based on the previous studies and the XPS spectra of Ag 3d and Mn 2p, there was a noticeable correlation among Ag+, Mn4+ and Ce3+ content, which inferred that there were redox cycles among Ag, Mn and Ce species as follows: Ag0+Ce4+⇋Ag++Ce3+, Mn3++Ce4+⇋Mn4++Ce3+ [56,58]. The reactions were beneficial to form the electron holes as well as the unsaturated chemical bonds, thus promoted the amount of surface active oxygen and the redox property of Ce-Ti catalyst at low temperature. What's more, the O1s spectra was displayed in Fig. 6d, which existed in two characteristic peaks. The peak at higher binding energy (529.3–529.8 eV) could be assigned to chemisorbed oxygen Oα, such as O− and O2 2−. The other peak at lower binding energy (528.3 eV) could be referred to lattice oxygen Oβ. Compared with Oβ, it was well established that Oα showed better mobility and oxidizability, resulting in its better oxidation performance [59,60]. As shown in Table 2, it was visible that the order of the proportion of Oα/(Oα+Oβ) was Ag8-Mn/Ce-Ti > Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti > Ag2-Mn/Ce-Ti > Mn/Ce-Ti > Ce-Ti. As stated above, the redox cycles among Ag, Mn and Ce could boost the creation of surface active oxygen, which was consistent with the proportion of Oα/(Oα+Oβ). The chemisorbed oxygen could not only promote the oxidation of NH3, but also provide benefits to the oxidation from NO to NO2 to achieve “Fast SCR Reaction” and then improve SCR performance [34]. Hence, Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti showed better NH3-SCO and NH3-SCR activity at low temperature in comparison with Mn/Ce-Ti and Ce-Ti catalyst for the reason that Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst presented more Oα owing to the redox cycles among Ag, Mn and Ce species. In addition, more Ag modification was more conducive to improve the catalytic performance at low temperature. 3.9 NH3-TPD NH3-TPD was used to investigate the chemisorption of NH3 on the surface of different catalysts, which was a crucial part of NH3-SCO and SCR process. As shown in Fig. 7 , it was evidently that all samples presented a characteristic peak at low temperature region (around 150 °C), which could be assigned to weak acidic sites [48]. Compared with raw Ce-Ti catalyst, Ag and Mn modification slightly decreased the strength of weak acidic sites. The possible reason was that the loaded Ag and Mn species covered some acidic sites on the surface of Ce-Ti sample [60]. With regard to the medium acidic sites, four modified Ce-Ti catalysts showed a small peak at medium temperature region (around 350 °C) and there was no obvious peak for raw Ce-Ti catalyst. Moreover, in comparison with weak and medium acidic sites, it was well established that strong acidic sites were more active in the chemisorption of NH3 [31]. Apparently, no characteristic peak could be detected for Ce-Ti catalyst at high temperature region. The other four samples all showed characteristic peaks representing strong acidic sites at around 700 °C. The loading of Ag could significantly increase the area of the peak. More Ag modification resulted in the larger amount of strong acidic sites on Ce-Ti catalyst surface. Based on the calculation of the peak area, the ratio of the surface acidity of Ce-Ti, Mn/Ce-Ti, Ag2-Mn/Ce-Ti, Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti and Ag8-Mn/Ce-Ti was 1:1.13:1.30:1.36:1.37. In conclusion, Ag and Mn species were conducive to the chemisorption of NH3 by increasing the strength and amount of the acidic sites on the sample surface. Among these samples, Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti and Ag8-Mn/Ce-Ti catalysts showed better surface acid properties, which could contribute to their better catalytic performance. 3.10 H2-TPR In order to obtain a better comprehension of the influence of redox capacity on SCO and SCR reactions, H2-TPR experiment was examined over Ce-Ti. Mn/Ce-Ti and Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalysts. As displayed in Fig. 8 , Ce-Ti catalyst showed a broad and weak peak from 300 to 700 °C, which could be attributed to the sequential reduction of lattice oxygen and chemisorbed oxygen as well as the reduction from Ce4+ to Ce3+ [51,58]. When Mn was introduced in Ce-Ti catalyst, the peak area became larger and the peak temperature became lower, suggesting its better redox capacity. To be specific, the characteristic peak at 347 °C belonged to the reduction of Mn oxides and the other obvious peak at 436 °C belonged to the interaction between Mn and Ce species [34,58], which was consistent with XPS analysis. With respect to Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalysts, all the three samples showed similar peak position at low temperature. The main peaks at 110–120 °C could be assigned to Ag oxides reduction. The other small peaks at 180–200 °C could be identified as the synergistic effect among Ag, Mn and Ce oxides [56]. Obviously, the peak temperature of Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti was much lower and the peak area was much higher, which confirmed that Ag modification could significantly enhance the redox ability. What's more, it could be found that the peak area increased with the rise of Ag amount, indicating that more Ag could lead to stronger redox ability. Overall, the consequence of H2-TPR analysis was basically in agreement with the SCO and SCR activity measurement results. 3.11 Discussion From the above, it was clear that Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalysts exhibited excellent low temperature NH3-SCO and NH3-SCR performance and the redox ability was enhanced along with the rise of the amount of Ag. Based on the current researches, the NH3 oxidation process obeyed i-SCR mechanism, which was similar to SCR process [34,42,48]. The whole reaction consisted of three steps. The first stage was NH3 chemisorption process. The gaseous NH3 was chemisorbed on the surface acidic sites of the catalyst and create NH3(ad) to participate in the further process (Eq. (9)) [48,61]. As displayed in NH3-TPD section, the addition of Mn and Ag could dramatically promote the amount and strength of the surface acidic sites of the sample and the promotion effect of Ag was more obvious, which was advantageous to NH3 chemisorption, which was the basic process of SCO and SCR reaction. Subsequently, the second step was the activation of absorbed NH3 by surface active oxygen (Eq. (10)) [48,62]. XPS and H2-TPR results indicated that the interactions and redox cycles among Ag, Mn and Ce species could provide abundant chemisorbed oxygen and more surface Mn4+. It was well established that chemisorbed oxygen was more active in oxidation reaction due to its high mobility and oxidizability and surface Mn4+ could also bring advantages to oxidation reaction, which could be beneficial to the formation of surface active oxygen by O2. In other words, the synergistic effect between silver and manganese could significantly improve the redox property of the catalysts, thus enhanced the catalytic performance. The obtained results could explain the promotion effects of Ag introduction. (9) N H 3 ( g ) → N H 3 ( a d ) (10) N H 3 ( a d ) + O * → N H 2 * The last part was SCO and SCR reaction process. The activated NH2* first reacted with oxygen to generate absorbed NOx Eq. (11)). Then the NH2* was oxidized by NOx(ad) to create final product H2O and N2 (Eq. (12)). Meanwhile, NOx(ad) could also be oxidized by O* to form NO3(ad) and NO2(ad) * and then participate in the oxidation of NH2* (Eqs. (13) and ((14)) [44,47,48]. (11) N H 2 * + O 2 → N O x ( a d ) (12) N H 2 * + N O x → N 2 + H 2 O (13) N O x + O * → N O 3 ( a d ) + N O 2 ( a d ) * (14) N O 3 ( a d ) + N O 2 ( a d ) * + N H 2 * → N 2 + H 2 O When NO was introduced in the flue gas, the step of NH2* oxidation (Eq. (11)) could be skipped, thus improved the catalytic efficiency. Hence, NH3-SCR reaction had higher efficiency than NH3-SCO reaction and also showed lower active temperature. Moreover, SO2 was considered to inhibit the oxidation of NH2* to NOx(ad) [51,59]. Therefore, NO addition could improve the sulfur resistance of the sample to some extent. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of Aga−Mn/Ce-Ti catalysts (a = 2%,5%,8%) were synthetized by sol-gel and impregnation methods and applied in NOx and slip NH3 removal at low temperature. The activity tests confirmed that Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst showed an excellent low-temperature performance. To be specific, its NO conversion was 100%, NH3 conversion was above 95% and N2 selectivity was more than 90% between 150 and 300 °C. What's more, considering the oxidation of slip ammonia, Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst also exhibited above 90% NH3 conversion at 200–350 °C in the absence of NO. Additionally, the catalyst also exhibited good resistance to the harmful gas components in the flue gas, SO2 and H2O. The good sulfur resistance could be attributed to that Ce could preferentially react with SO2 to create sulfate, thus protected the active component. The enhanced surface acidity of Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti sample could bring benefits to NH3 adsorption. What's more, the excellent redox capacity of Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst could be assigned to the abundant active oxygen on the catalyst surface derived from the redox cycles among Ag, Mn and Ce oxides, thus improved the catalytic property at low temperature. The results in this research provided a novel catalyst with high efficiency in low-temperature SCR and SCO reaction, which was hopeful to solve ammonia escape problems and improve the stability of system operation in practical engineering while realizing low-temperature denitrification. coredata.dc:description: Low temperature SCR has been a promising technology due to the diverse load in coal-fired plants. However, ammonia escape problem could be more serious at low temperature on account of the condensation of NH4HSO4, resulting in deactivation of SCR catalyst and equipment corrosion. NH3-SCO technology could oxidize slip ammonia to harmless N2. Hence, it is important to develop a novel catalyst with high SCR and SCO efficiency at low temperature to remove NOx and slip NH3 and achieve the stable operation of SCR system. In this work, a combined sol-gel and impregnation method was used to synthetize different Aga−Mn/Ce-Ti (a = 2%, 5%, 8%) catalysts and applied in NOx and slip NH3 removal at low temperature. The activity measurement confirmed that Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst exhibited an excellent low-temperature performance. At 150–300 °C, its NO conversion was 100%, NH3 conversion was above 95% and N2 selectivity was more than 90%. Moreover, considering the oxidation of slip ammonia, Ag5-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst also exhibited above 90% NH3 conversion at 200–350 °C in the absence of NO. The catalytic performance could also be kept at a high level under the existence of SO2 and H2O. The characteristic results revealed that Ag and Mn modification could not apparently change the phase structure and could decrease the BET area to some extent. In addition, Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst possessed stronger and more surface acidic sites and contributed to better NH3 adsorption capacity. Besides, there was more chemisorbed oxygen on Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst resulting from the interactions among Ag, Mn and Ce oxides, which was responsible for its better redox property.
coredata.dc:title: Excellent low temperature NH3-SCR and NH3-SCO performance over Ag-Mn/Ce-Ti catalyst: Evaluation and characterization
